divs: sighting details early in the morning of thurs. 10\27 (today), my friend and i were driving northeast on i95 between new haven ct. and providence, ri. at about 3:18 or 3:19 am we were both looking straight ahead and my friend was talking, and we had some rock music on. we had just passed exit 2, and the night was extremely clear. all of a sudden, ahead of us and a bit to the right something lit up, traveled directly downward, and then was gone again after a little more or less than a second. i thought it disappeared well before it hit the tree line. its distance from us was difficult to determine because of the darkness and the brightness of the object, but its speed was extraordinary- it must have covered a few thousand feet in that moment we saw it. i could not have blocked it with the head of a pin at arm's length, but would have easily blocked it out with a small capsule of medicine at the same distance. the way it lit up and left a light trail because of its speed and then disappeared has since reminded me of a firefly or spark in the fireplace. i thought it might have been a plane at first, but it was traveling far to fast, and straight down. in reviewing it to try to explain it, i was immediately certain that it had too much downward velocity to be a falling object from this planet- it would have had to unnaturally accelerate downwards to reach that speed, which means something either from outside the atmosphere or with rather impressive engines. when it happened i immediately sat forward and tried to account for it, and second-guessed myself for an instant until my friend exclaimed loudly, turned the music down and asked me "did you just see that?" our perceptions of it were slightly different, even though we had both been looking essentially straight at it. he thought, and i agreed, that for it to be an airplane was impossible because of the speed unless it was a fighter jet flying directly into the earth. i thought it might have had a slight arc to it, but couldn't be sure, whereas he thought it was entirely straight down. we both remarked at how bright it had been. certainly it must have been at least several miles away, and probably a bit farther than that, although the darkness and the light of the object made it difficult to tell, we agreed. we differed most on the perception of color: he thought it was blue, and i thought it was white. it reminded both of us of a shooting star- the way it lit up brightly, traveled, and disappeared- but we could not account for its angle or proximity. as he drove the rest of the way to providence, i spent the drive searching the sky for any repetition, of which there was none. the event had lasted just a second, maybe a little more or less, but we were completely at a loss to explain it. the only thing that makes sense to me is if a meteorite suddenly lit up (although it should have done so on entering the atmosphere) and then burned itself up again. i have not been able, however, to find any prediction of, record of, or reference to any such event thus far.
